children.name: Suppose that you could solve problem A in polynomial time.
keywords: Suppose that you could solve problem A in polynomial time.

children.name: Then every problem B ∈ NP can also be solved in polynomial time
keywords: Then every problem B ∈ NP can also be solved in polynomial time

children.name: There is a reduction from B to A, which preserves polynomial time.
keywords: There is a reduction from B to A, which preserves polynomial time.

children.name: this can mean several things
Turing reductions
Deterministic polynomial time Turing reduction
Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask oracle queries to problem A.
keywords: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask oracle queries to problem A.

children.name: Machines with oracles
Machines with oracles
A Turing machine with oracle A ⊆ Γ* is defined as follows.
keywords: A Turing machine with oracle A ⊆ Γ* is defined as follows.

children.name: maybe deterministic or nondeterministic
The machine has two tapes, input tape and oracle tape. Initially, the input tape contains the input word and the oracle tape is empty.
keywords: The machine has two tapes, input tape and oracle tape. Initially, the input tape contains the input word and the oracle tape is empty.

children.name: The machine can execute an oracle query (in unit time). If the word on the oracle tape belongs to A, then the oracle tape is replaced by “yes”, otherwise the second tape is replaced by “no”.
keywords: The machine can execute an oracle query (in unit time). If the word on the oracle tape belongs to A, then the oracle tape is replaced by “yes”, otherwise the second tape is replaced by “no”.

children.name: B ≤ A
keywords: solvable in deterministic polynomial time with oracle A

children.name: Fact. If B ≤ A and A ∈ P, then B ∈ P
keywords: Fact. If B ≤ A and A ∈ P, then B ∈ P

children.name: Fact. For every problem B ∈ NP, B ≤ “NP halting problem”
keywords: Fact. For every problem B ∈ NP, B ≤ “NP halting problem”

children.name: Therefore, if the NP halting problem is in P, then P = NP.
keywords: Therefore, if the NP halting problem is in P, then P = NP.

children.name: Attention: this is not the usual notion of reduction for NP-completeness
keywords: Attention: this is not the usual notion of reduction for NP-completeness

children.name: Also makes sense for exponential time, or logarithmic space, etc.
keywords: Also makes sense for exponential time, or logarithmic space, etc.

children.name: Karp reductions
Deterministic polynomial time Karp reduction
Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask one oracle query to A, at the end of its computation, and respond with the oracle answer.
keywords: Idea. Problem B can be solved by a deterministic polynomial time Turing machine, which is allowed to ask one oracle query to A, at the end of its computation, and respond with the oracle answer.

children.name: Σ*
we call this a polynomial time reduction
keywords: we call this a polynomial time reduction

children.name: If there is a Karp reduction, then there is a Turing reduction.
keywords: If there is a Karp reduction, then there is a Turing reduction.

children.name: The “NP halting problem” is complete already with respect to Karp reductions.
keywords: The “NP halting problem” is complete already with respect to Karp reductions.

children.name: Why?
Why Karp?
Karp reduction can distinguish problems that are interreducible with respect to Turing reductions.
keywords: Karp reduction can distinguish problems that are interreducible with respect to Turing reductions.

NP complete
Definition. A language A is called NP-complete if: 1. it belongs to NP 2. every language L ∈ NP reduces to A
keywords: Definition. A language A is called NP-complete if: 1. it belongs to NP 2. every language L ∈ NP reduces to A
